docs.lead_paragraph: The schools, created in the 1960s, have been marked by low test scores, poor attendance and inadequate facilities.

headline.main: New York’s Schools for Pregnant Girls Will Close
headline.print_headline: Schools for Pregnant Girls, Relic Of 1960s New York, Will Close

docs.snippet: The schools, created in the 1960s, have been marked by low test scores, poor attendance and inadequate facilities.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 China Reaches Into Space To Exert Power on Earth China last week launched a communications satellite for Nigeria in a project that serves as an example of Beijing's efforts to position itself as a space benefactor to the developing world and of how space has become another arena where China is trying to exert its soft power. A1 Found Body May Be Missing G.I. The American military started examining a body found in the Euphrates River that Iraqi authorities and local residents believe is one of three American soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12. A16 President Bush, addressing head-on the criticism that Iraq has turned into another Vietnam, argued that withdrawing from Iraq would be dangerous because, unlike the enemy in Vietnam, terrorists in Iraq were capable and had the desire to strike Americans at home. A16 Rival Palestinian Leaders Meet The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, met secretly Tuesday with Prime Minister Ismail Haniya of Hamas to try to reach a cease-fire between their factions, Mr. Haniya's spokesman said. A6 Turkey Vows to Confront Kurds The Turkish prime minister said he would move against Kurdish militants in northern Iraq if necessary, hours after authorities said the perpetrator of a suicide bomb attack in Ankara was from a Kurdish city. A8 NATIONAL A18-25 Former Justice Dept. Aide Testifies on Hiring Tactics A former top Justice Department aide, Monica Goodling, testified that she ''crossed the line'' in considering the political beliefs of applicants for nonpartisan legal jobs and suggested that earlier testimony by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and another top official might have been flawed. A1 Safety Candidate Withdraws A senior lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers withdrew his nomination to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the association was preparing to give him. A18 Calls to Pass Immigration Bill The No. 2 Republican in the Senate, Trent Lott of Mississippi, made an all-out pitch for support of a comprehensive immigration bill as the Senate voted to slash the size of a proposed guest worker program, infuriating employers. A24 Findings in Hurricane Study Over the last 5,000 years, the eastern Caribbean has experienced several periods, lasting centuries, in which strong hurricanes occurred frequently even though ocean temperatures were cooler than those measured today, according to a new study. The analysis is being published in the journal Nature. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 9/11 Claims Settled After Battle With Insurers The Spitzer administration announced the settlement of all insurance claims at ground zero, ensuring that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site. The agreement brought to an end a protracted and bitter legal battle. A1 Pregnant Girls to Lose Schools New York City plans to shut its four remaining high schools for pregnant girls as part of a sweeping reorganization. Pregnancy schools across the country appear to be slowly fading away, partly because of the declining rate of teenage pregnancy. A1 9/11 Dust Linked to Death New York City's chief medical examiner has for the first time directly linked a death to exposure to dust from the destruction of the World Trade Center. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-13 Gas Prices Continue to Spike Gas prices are spiking, and oil executives warn that current fuel shortages could lead to stubbornly higher prices at the pump. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: Witness for the prosecutors; giving juvenile offenders a chance; killing the Russian media; our whistle-blower friends. Columns: Atul Gawande and Nicholas D. Kristof. Bridge E8 TV Listings E1 Crossword E2 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. approved the pill, called Lybrel and made by Wyeth, that can halt menstrual periods indefinitely and prevent pregnancies.

headline.main: The Vegans and Their Children (6 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Death by Veganism,'' by Nina Planck (Op-Ed, May 21): I am a nutritionist who testified as an expert witness for the prosecution in the criminal trial of the parents of Crown Shakur. As the lead prosecutor in this case told the jury, this poor infant was not killed by a vegan diet. He was starved to death by parents who did not give him breast milk, soy-based infant formula or enough food of any kind.
docs.abstract: Six letters comment on Nina Planck's May 21 Op-Ed article arguing that children should not be raised on vegan diet; Amy Joy Lanou, nutrition scientist who testified in trial of Atlanta couple cited in article, says their infant died from starvation, not from vegan diet; Ross Smith says diet that may be adequate for adult is not always good for baby or child; Nicole Speer says well-planned vegan diets have been shown repeatedly to be sufficient and even beneficial at all stages of life; Lynette C Kelly says adult vegan can enjoy robust physical health; George Mazzei says it is appalling that anyone would think diet based on dubious morality would build human infant; Zoe Weil says she has raised healthy vegan child since conception; drawing
